moves.1. e4: This is only my second game, trying out the Traxler counter gambit. As always, it's a fierce opening which leads to a quick defeat for white after 12 moves.
moves.4. Ng5: White goes on the attack, bringing forward the knight
moves.4... Bc5: So black counter attacks with the bishop
moves.5. Nxf7: This is possibly the more dangerous line for white to take at this point, but also the quickest route to material advantage.
moves.5... Bxf2+: Take that! - black invites white to take the bishop - opening up all sorts of nasty possibilities for black counterplay
moves.6. Kf1: Black wisely declines to take the bishop for now and heads for cover on the f file
moves.6... Qe7: The black queen moves to safety
moves.7. Nxh8: White chews up the available material
moves.7... d5: Black attacks and opens the diagonal for the LSB
moves.8. exd5: p X p attacking the knight on C6
moves.8... Nd4: So the knight joins the attack, moving to d4
moves.9. h3: White pushes the pawn to try and prevent the bishop on C1 staring down the queen on g4
moves.9... Ne4: So now the second knight joins the attack, creating a formidable centre
moves.10. c3: White tries to push the knight from its perch
moves.10... Qf6: Black ignores the threat and creates an instant threat of its own down the f file
moves.11. g4: White tries to create an escape hatch, but it's all over
moves.11... Bg3+: Bishop to g3 check (or to e1) leaves the King facing mate on the next move

opening: two knights defence (C57), Wilkes Barre (Traxler) variation
